subject: Education
title: Peer Assessment: Learning by Judging Others' Work
description: A quick, practical guide to Peer Assessment: Learning by Judging Others' Work.

hook.text: Students learn more from grading five essays than from writing one. Surprised?

buildup.text: Peer assessment asks students to evaluate classmates' work against clear criteria.

discovery.text: Evaluating others' work develops critical judgment that students then apply to their own.

twist.text: Students often resistâ€”they doubt peers' competence and fear social consequences of honest critique.

climax.text: With structured rubrics and practice, peer assessment becomes as reliable as teacher grading.

punchline.text: Judging others' work teaches you to judge your own.

quiz.question: Why does peer assessment benefit the assessor more than the assessed?
options: Evaluating work develops critical judgment that transfers to self-improvement
Students enjoy having power over their classmates
Peer assessment is always more accurate than teacher grading
